title: Sydney Tomsick
text:
I’m a fourth-year Statistics and Data Science major at UCLA, with a minor in Digital Humanities. With a multidisciplinary background in data science, UX design, marketing, and arts administration, I enjoy working at the intersection of quantitative analysis and creative storytelling: translating complex data into well-designed digital content and outreach strategies that resonate with people. Outside of academics, I’m a director of Synthesis Dance Theater, a student-run dance company at UCLA.
Download My Resume here.
Go to the Projects page to see other projects I have worked on for class and in my free time!

title: Exploring Female Representation in MoMA
text:
My team and I created a website discussing the lack of female representation in art museums. We used this dataset created by the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) to make visualizations showing how female artist representation has changed in MoMA overtime both in the US and globally. Using our research, we discussed potential connections between changes in gender representation in MoMA and feminist movements taking place at the same time.

Our Research Questions

How did waves of feminism and American social movements of the mid-1900s affect the representation of American female artists in the MoMA collection? 
Beyond the U.S., how did global feminist movements relate to the ethnic diversity of female artists in the MoMA collection?



My Responsibilities
My main responsibility in this project was web design through WordPress. I also helped clean the data and create data visualizations.

title: Exploring Female Representation in MoMA
text: For this project, Exploring Female Representation in MoMA, my team and I designed a website exploring the underrepresentation of female artists in major art institutions, with a focus on the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) in New York. Using the publicly available Artworks.csv dataset from MoMA’s GitHub repository—which includes information on artwork titles, artist demographics, acquisition dates, and exhibition status—we analyzed how female artist representation in MoMA has shifted over time for domestic and international artists. We created data visualizations in Tableau to illustrate these trends and contextualized our findings by drawing connections to key waves of feminist activism. My primary contributions included designing the website in WordPress, cleaning and preparing the dataset, and creating visualizations to communicate our insights.

title: A Clinical Study: The Effect of Caffeine and Exercise on Attention
text: In this clinical study, The Effect of Caffeine and Exercise on Attention, I investigated whether caffeine intake and running distance significantly impact attention span using a 2-way factorial design with interactions. Both factors had three levels—caffeine (250mL green tea, 250mL coffee, 500mL coffee) and exercise (100m, 1km, 5km)—creating nine experimental groups. The study was conducted using The Island, an online simulation platform that allowed me to administer treatments and measure attention in simulated individuals. ANOVA and Tukey’s post-hoc tests revealed no statistically significant effect from caffeine, exercise, or their interaction on attention span, suggesting these variables do not meaningfully impact attentional performance in the context of this simulation.

title: Kaggle Competition: Predicting Obesity Status
text: In this team project, Predicting Obesity Status Based on Genetic and Lifestyle Factors, we aimed to predict individuals’ obesity status using a dataset of 42,686 observations with 29 predictors spanning dietary habits, physical activity, water intake, and family history. After imputing missing values with random forest methods, we evaluated several classification models including logistic regression, decision trees, and random forests. Our final model, a random forest with 500 trees, achieved a testing accuracy of 99.943%. We also used correlation analysis and variable importance rankings to identify the most influential predictors, which included frequent consumption of high-calorie foods (FAVC), physical activity frequency (FAF), water intake (CH2O), number of main meals (NCP), and family history of being overweight.

title: Altadena and The Eaton Fire
text: In Altadena and the Eaton Fire, my team and I developed an interactive website using ArcGIS StoryMaps to examine the disproportionate impacts of the 2023 Eaton Fire on historically marginalized communities in Altadena, California. The first half of our project uses spatial data—including Cal Fire’s Damage Inspection (DINS) reports, HOLC redlining maps, and U.S. Census data—to investigate how redlining and discriminatory housing policies have shaped present-day vulnerability to wildfire damage. The second half shifts to a more human-centered narrative, examining the fire’s impact on Altadena’s cultural landscape through the loss of historic landmarks, small businesses, and individual homes, many tied to long-standing Black and Latinx families. Together, these stories and spatial patterns reveal how past and present injustices shape who bears the brunt of climate disasters.

title: The Social Soundscape: How Social Media Impacts Music Popularity
text: In our project, The Social Soundscape: How Social Media Impacts Music Popularity, my team and I analyzed a dataset of over 4,000 songs with the highest Spotify streams in 2024, incorporating data from YouTube, TikTok, Apple Music, and other platforms. We explored three key questions: whether a song’s release month affects its popularity, how genre performance varies across platforms, and the relationship between TikTok engagement and Spotify streams. I led the data cleaning process and conducted the analysis for our first research question, using the Kruskal-Wallis test and Wilcoxon post-hoc comparisons after finding ANOVA assumptions were violated. We found that songs released in January saw significantly higher Spotify streams, likely due to seasonal trends. Our findings offer insights for artists and marketers on how timing and platform strategy can shape a song’s success in today’s algorithm-driven music landscape.

title: UX Design for Snagged
text: I conceptualized and designed “Snagged”: an app for style-conscious thrifters who want to discover new thrift stores, rate and review their experiences, and share their journey with friends. My whole process of designing “Snagged” can be found on this website; from user interviews and personas to wireframes and the final design.

title: Client Project: A Statistical Analysis of the Informed Placement Process (IPP) at UCLA
text: This client project, A Statistical Analysis of the Informed Placement Process (IPP) at UCLA, was completed for the UCLA English Department, which aimed to understand how self-assessments and demographic factors influence incoming students’ English placement outcomes. Using data from 980 students, we built logistic and linear regression models to examine how writing confidence and structural inequities affect placement results. We found that higher self-reported confidence reduced the need for a second evaluator, while underrepresented minority students were more likely to be placed in lower-level courses, pointing to potential disparities in the placement process.
